physDesc.p: Two pages typewritten in black ink. Address given for H. D. in the top left corner of the first page: Mrs. Richard Aldington care of Mrs. Randall, 3 Christchurch Place London, N.W. England. Unsigned. Includes a postscript.

editorialDecl.p: This letter contains references to the following:

body.p: I got your very nice letter from Mullion a few days ago, and also your poems, but, in the first place, let me congratulate you on the birth of your daughter. I did congratulate Richard, and I meant to write to you long ago, but I have been swamped with the proof of my new book. Both Mrs. Russell and I are perfectly delighted to know that everything passed over so successfully, and that you are entirely recovered from the pneumonia. You do not know, dear Hilda, how fond I am of you and how much your happiness means to me.

You speak of wanting to be in a warmer place for the Winter. I suppose nothing could induce you to come to America. It would be so nice to have you here, and I quite agree with Winifred Ellerman in thinking that this is the place for poetry now. I make no doubt that I can dispose of your poems satisfactorily, and I shall set about it at once. Do not worry about not being dans le movement. The "Movement" as I now see it is mostly an artificial one, and I believe that the better poets will always write as they feel without any regard for the fashionable thing in the minds of les jeunes</>. I have seen so many movements go under since I have been on the tapis that I am no longer worried about the fate of anything that is really good, and I think it is rather an advantage to be out of it than otherwise. I have been in it for years and have borne the brunt of ridicule, jests, diatribes, and am now reaping the benefit of a reasonable success, but the result of it all to me has been to make me feel that one must write as one wishes, and that one can force the public to take it if it is good. You have no idea of the exaltation of poetry here in America. I have been asked to compile a Book Shelf of Modern Poets by Doubleday, Page & Company suitable for sale in department stores and railway terminals. Conceive of such a thing! All this love for poetry naturally is not very critical.

I think that your idea of sending Winifred over here is just the proper one, but I wish that you would send yourself and your little daughter over too. We need you, and I am just cheeky enough to think that you need us.
This takes lots and lots of love from Mrs. Russell and me.
body.postscript: P.S. I will write again when I have disposed of the poems.
